The measures pursued. and pursuing against the
Spaniards will produce, think. great changes on
the commerce Of this country, extracting large por
tons of capital and leaving the country very pour
will become more difficult TO effect sales and ex-
ceednsly dangerous to allow credits. In Jasco
the Spaniards have been expelled all soteros, and
those not married before 92l and that in the space
Of twenty days. In Acapulco, they have all been
driven to embark on board such vessels as were in

ted, and in Cuennayaca, abnut DAVIS travel from

and it is proposed in the Legislature of the State of
Mexico. that all, without exception, shall be expe-
ed the State. In fact, the movement appears to be
general, Congress will not pass a law to expel them


the country the several states it would seem are


in league to effect it individually. Many tired of
being hunted down in this manner, have resolved
themselves to leave, and suppose in twelve months
or less, there will not be an old Spanard in the Re-
public. These are the occurrences and news of the
day, from which you can draw your own differences
of the probable future condition of this country. my
own opinion is that things are going from bad to

from Rio de Janeiro, brings advices from that CAPT
tai to the s2d September. Commercial matters
were much in the same state as at the date of the
previous accounts. Markets for American produce
dull and overstocked, and the produce of the coun-

We have received from friends in different parts
Of Virginia, as well as through the newspapers of
the state, numerous accounts of county meetings,
in addition to those heretofore noticed. The eleva
Ell character, as well as the number of the citizens
who have attended these meetings, render them
truly imposing, and justify the hope that this distn
guished Commonwealth will, at the approaching
crisis of the Institutions of the Republic, be found
on the side which compors with her ancient fame
and her undertaking support of free sovernment.-
The proceedings of several of these meetings we
have, by special resolution. been requested to pub


ish Mt large and we would cheeriuy comply, com
ing as the requests do from individuals Of SO much
respectability, many of them subscribers to pa
per, if it were not tnat compliance would exact al
most all the space of our columns. We should feel
indeed. much pleasure in publishing these proceed
ings at large. as they are in every case, accompa-
med by addresses remarkable for just views Of
publican government for their temper and ability,
and every way worthy of the citizens of free and
enlightened State. Our limits however. and the
claims of other subjects, compel us to iorego this
pleasure, and to conne notices of the Virginia


meetings to summary statements.

From the National HfeHgencer, Nov. IA.
PUBLIC SENTIMENT IN VIRGINIA.

Papers to the 18th October, represent the secret
sucetes of Furkiss and Scotch as if good deal Vt
rivalry still existed between them. A new society
appears to have been recently formed, which has n-
voked the protection Of the Virgin in public process
sion. The editor Of the Vera Cruz .Noticoso'
defends Mr. Ponsett and MIR. Ward, against an att
tack made in an article in the London Times, re-
published in Mexico. He calls the United States
the country naturally most friendly to Mexico.
FROM VERA CRTIZE.

THE Board of Directors of the De'a,Uare fire
Insurance Company, have this day declared Dlv-
dcnd of three per cent for the last six MONTHS ON
the capital paid, which will be payable to the Stock
holders, or their legal representatives, on or after
the 18th inst at the Bank of Wilmington and Bran
dywine.

Dividend.

Mr.. Cliaton.-The political course which the
Statesman has thought proper to take in regard to
the Presidency, renders it proper for the editors
plicitly to ayow that neither Gov. Clinton nor his
friends in any degree implicated in the senti-
ments it may express.


Domestic yMammfactures.-A public meeting of the
citizens of Fredericksburg to have been held on
Saturday last, Sd inst to take into consideration the
expediency of creating company for the manufac-
ture of Wollen and Cotton Cloths and Linens.


Marriage Question. The Presbytery Of N. York
has unanimously decided to erase the section of the
confession of faith forbidding to marry his
wfes sister. The Presbytery of New Brunswick
has come to the same determination, l2 to s. The
Presbyteries of New Castle, Ohio, Redstone, Win
chester, and Philadelphia, have voted to retain the
section.


Snow fell at Boston on the night of the 7th
Inst 1t was followed by rain, again succeeded by
snow.-The wind was strong and chilly from the N
East There was also snow-storm on the North
River, about the same time.


The Salem Register Of Thursday says


yesterday, we had 4 cold and dsagreeable
storm, and considerable snow fell during the day.
Last evening the storm continued with violence, and
had all the characteristics Of an old fashioned Winter
Snow Storm The thermometer at O'Clock, was
at 81 above zero. This morning the storm has
aba'ed, but the ground is covered with and ice.


The Litchfeld Post. Conn also speaks of the
fall Of snow having been considerable in that part
f the country.


1t commenced showing at Providence on Tuesday
night and continued without ntprmssion on We'd
nesday. There was sufficient depth for sleghing.

London New Times of 4th of October:-


City, WeAnesday euerng


In the early part of the day the transactions in
the English Funds were of the most limited, char
acer, and the price Of Consuls nearly stationary,
alternately buyers and sellers at 81. Towards the
close Of the market, however, on the rumour
which was circulated with confidence that the Egypa
tian fleet had landed troops at Hydra, and had de-
stroyed moi only the garrison. but the chief of the
inhabitants. decline took place. and the price fell
to Sc rs 81 for Account, at which rate they ef, off
after having been 81 l-S. AT late hour in the day.
however, notice was placed on the board at lioy-
eds from the agent, under date Malta the l2th Sept.
stating that the Egyptian fleet, consisting of eighty
sail, had been fallen in with bound to the Morea, and
that Vice Admiral Sir Z. Codrington had left Smyr-
ma with twelve sail on the lst and Cd September
it also added that his Maiesty's ship Dyad and
the Hind cutter sailed from Malta to JOIN the Bri-
tish Admiral.


This threw some discredit on the original report,
but still the rumour for the moment caused very
unpleasant sensation, forit was stated that the Is
land of II, dra, which was at one time the seat Of
the Greek Government. had experienced the same
melancholy fate as those of lpsara and Reio.
ENGLAND.

The following appears by way of Postscriptto to the
London New Times of 4th of October

BUENOS ATRES.


Since the foregoing paragraph was written, we
have been favored BY an esteemed friend with the
following extract of letter dated


'.RIo DE JANEIRo, 22d Sept. 1927.
s'Wc have no news here things in Baenos Ayres
have run into much disorder. The provinces have
separated from that Of Buenos Ayres, but are deter
mined to agree among themselves, and to carry on
the war for the independence Of the Banda Oriental
The former confederation is dissolved, and Buenos
Ayres is now under a local government. shese peo-
Pile the Rrazllians count more upon dissentons
among their enemies, than on their own abilities to
coerce peace.'
BuENOS AYRES.

THE President and Directors of the Bank Of DEL
a,care, have this day declared Dividend of Ten
Dollars per share equal to live per cent on the Cap
ital Stock for the last six months, payable to the
Stockholders, or their legal representatives on or
after the 10th inst


EDWARD WORRELL, Cash'r.
Nov 9, 1927. 60

From Me National Journal


We this day lay before our readers list Of
the members of the twentieth Congress, complete,
with the exception Of such have vel 10 be chosen
to fill the vacancies caused by the designations
of Mr.. Forsythe II Georgia, and Mr.. Evans, of
New York. and by the deaths of Mr.. Wilson of
Ohio, and Dr. Young Of Kentucky.


Baltimore Rail Rood.-The Managers of the
&C Baltimore and Ohio Rail Company have recev-
ed report from the Engineers, employed to survey
the several routes proposed for the Road, who re-
port that the Road is practicable, by more than one
route, though no particular one is recommended. In
cons equence of which, the Company have advertis-
ed for Timber and iron for the construction of the
Road, to be delivered in the city Of Baltimore on or
before July /, 1928.
From lie NGiional Journal.

The ship Hamilton, Capt. Bunker, arrived last
evening, having left Liverpool on the 3d. She brings
Liverpool papers Of the Sd, and London of the Cd
Of October, day later than those received by the
packet ship New-Tork.


Accounts from Corfu to the 29th of August have
been received in London. Achmed Pacha Of Patras,
his march to Vostizzo. had passed the monastery
of Tasiachi. where he found considerable number
of Greeks, who had taken possession of the place
without the consent of the Monks. very SAN
culinary contest took place, which terminated in the
surrender of the Greeks. The pacha afterwards
proceeded and arrived at Vostizzo with 1000 men
and 12 pieces of cannon. At Patras there was
force Of 5000 Turkish troops, who about to set
out for Modon, where Ibrahim pacha arrived on the
18th july


Spain insurrection goes on and speeds.
The rebels have appointed Regency and published
prOclanatinns in favor of .'the Absolute King =
rhe pretence is, that Ferdinand is not his own mas
ter. In the mean time the French garrisons per-
lectly quiet.


LoNDoN, Oct. 2.-Hamburgh papers of the 29th
ult reached Us last mig int. The loss sustained by
the town of Ambo by the late dreadful catastrophe
is estimated at no less than thirteen millions of rlx
dollars A terrible fire took place at Schwelin,
near Eberlield, on the 22d forty houses were
destroyed.


A manifesto of the Emperor Of Russia, dated / oh





whole Empire of two in every 500 inhabitants, not
even excepting the Jews, who have formerly been
exempt on payment Of pecuniary tax, which is to
be abolished This levy. it is supposed. will pro-
duce force of at least $50, 900 men, part of which
will have to supply the vacancies arising from death
and the discharges of those who have served their e
gal time.


MIR. Galain. the American Minister, had an in
tervew with the Earl ol Dudley, at tie Foreign of
flee.


Ledia-Late adyices from India inform us, that
severe battle has been fought in Upper India, be-
tween numerous body of the Afghan tribes, and
the troops OF ltajah Runjit Sinh. The Afghan ar
my consisted it is sad OF 90. 900 infantry Il 0,00(
horse. whilst that ef Runjit's amounted TO only be
tween 5000 and 10000 men. The armies met ~
the banks of the Indus. to the village of Seydeo
when the attack was commenced by the Afgh hans
but the greater part of their host being i'll armed ant
less organ iZed, made no impression on the Sikl1s
who put their enemies to the route In the fligh
great numbers were sabred by Runiits cavalry, and
body that bad taken shelter in the village of Sey
/ deo, was surrounded and entirely DESTROYED. The
Afgha MS lost 8 pieces of artillery. and about l0t
swvels, and their camp was punderedby the vie
/ tors


CoRFu, Sept. live have never seen such ac
tiyty in roads, and such regular communication
by post with the aeighbouring Greek Islands, al
now that the squadrons Of the Three Powers are OF
the point of joining together. Yesterday two fri
gates arrived, which are probably the rear of thu
Russian squadron, for we learn that Admiral Hey
den has been obliged by the west winds to steer II
the right Of Corfu and proceed by Strvali and Cap
Spathi to Milo, to effect his junction with the Frenc
and English squadrons. The Egyptian fleet whic
sailed from Alexandria on the 1stN of August, ha
probably received notice of the approaching junctio
Of the European squadrons, aad has endeaveured
avoid them for our last accounts from Nayarn
which come down to the 9th September, agree j
stating that not single Egyptian or Turkish YES
sci has yet been On those seas hence it is lr
Fl terred that the Egyptian fleet has either returned
; Alexandria, or that it has stecred another cours
to reach the Morca, or one of the Islands in til
: Archipelago.

the commerce Of this country, extracting large poi

rHEM. If they are to be found in his conduct in
Florida. where he placed himself, as the execu-
i've authority of the territory, above the Judiciary
and set the decisions of Judge Fromntin at detiante
making every thing to yield to his lncinations,
&C. &C. and ithey not to be found in those trans
actions, we should like 10 know 1ohen 0ere and ho7o
he acquired The character (of statesman.) In dis
cussing the qualifications OF men for office, 1hen aoe
consider them incompetent for the proper discharge
of the duties Of the stations, we wish to have nothing

ity"


;o;ce at his prosperity but we never wish to see
linn nlaced in situation in which his extraordinary
onergu NAV turn to the disadvantage of the country.
We are willing that he should be employed against
the foes ofthe nation. but not against ourselves"


The New York papers claim decided Jackson
majority of the members of the Legislature which
have lust been elected. That the great mass of the
people Of that state do prefer Andrew Jackson to
John Quincy Adams Cor the presidency it is not
rational to believe. But that Mr.. Van Buren may
have so made his arrangements that the result OF the
election should seem to indicate such preference,
we have no doubt. Such was his especial business
and such the cherished hope of the Combination.
Martin Van Buren is one of that small number Of
men, who must bid adieu to all hope of future poll
tical advancement, unless there can be brought
about complete revouton--a total prostration of
' the Administration. Unless the men in power
can be ruined by some means, two or three would be
presidents must be forever disappointed. The prize
. is great and it must be obtained soon, or never


Martin and his Argus had denounced General
Jackson, like other men and papers of the same
character but that was not to be considered.
when it was discovered that the best chance of de-
sroyng the Administration and creating vacancy
in few years was in supporting General Jackson
I that was the only chance Of success, the hazzard
Of any revolution caused by the election of the Ge
neral was not to be regarded.


1t was seen that the General already had the sup
port of large portion of the community. from va
ous causes, not very creditable to their understand
NO and intelligence in some cases, to their pa
rotism in others. But it was too well known that
ne could not succeed as the first choice Of the Ame
rcan people and hence the absolute necessity of
employing organization prosttuted presses and po-
iticans, and using all means, fair and foul. to de-
grade the Administration, SO that majority of the





choice of eyils.H Hence we have had tale after
ale the establishment of new presses the zeal of
hose prostitutes in Virginia, Delaware. and New
York and the labors of those second rate asprants
who have slight hopes of advancement under the
present order of things.


If the Van Buren majority in the New York Le-
Eisature--caIeh sonan---chuose to take away
The power of the people to vote by districts for the
president, they may gain something for the moment;
but such course will most assuredly ruin Mr.. Van
Burcn's ulterior projects.


Besdes-supposing we allow all that the Jackso-
nians claim in Newly orl--which we very far
from doing--the signs of the times clearly indicate
that Virginia will not be counted on the side of the
&opposton. Suppose Jackson avowedly hostile to
the American system, he would be hard pushed ir
Virginia, and would probably loose all the state;
North Of the Potomac If he were as decidedly il
favor Of the American System as the present Ad
nnistraton, what has Virginia to gain by the change
N that score, and what have the people north 0
'he Potomac, seeing more fully, by and by, the rea
ohjccts Of the aspirants, to hope from a change 0
men?


Thus, therefore, when Mr.. Van Buren arrive


at Washington, in few days, he may say that h
. has done his best, according to the Combination ar
j ansements but he has much harder task t
perorm-to reconcile Virginia, Pennsylvania, an


New York to General Jackson and the policy whic


he must adopt.


Though the advocates of the Hero are SO highl


excited by the Combination operations in Newly orl
9 hey are vastly mistaken if they suppose the battle
!, won. We have yet to learn whether the people !


mat State generally, In their late vote, suppose

the history of Gen. Jackson's accusations AGAINST

LONDON, Uct. A.
The Turks at Prevesa having heard of the decla-
ration of the allied powers, were filled with appre4
tensions, and had sent a pressing application to
Redchd Pacha for reinforcements, without which
they said that they could not prevent that fortress
from falling into the hands of the ireeks il it should
be attacked


PARIs, Sept. 80.
A report is spread. that the affairs of the Greeks
had taken more favorable turn; that Russian
Consul to the Greek Government has been appoint
ed, and that the Count Capo DIstria was going to
be officially recognised as President of Greece by
the three Allied Powers


SPAIN.


Letters from Saragossa say that conspiracy IN
favor of the rebels Of Catalonia had been discover
cd in that city, and that twenty persons Of distnc-
ton had been arrested, among whom are Mai. Gen.
Aran Frigllo, Guerilla Chief during the time OF
the constitutions Col Leon Il Brlgadier, and the
brothers Of Generals Capape and Fryre.
GyMNAsrIc. The following account of swim
ming school at Amberg. in Bavaria. we find in the
New York Statesman, taken from the papers of that
country. which give splendid accounts OF the success
of some of the scholars


The soldiers of regiment of infantry were ena-
bled to 20 down "a feet under waer and swan about
from an hour to an hour and half. They jumped
from an elevation of SO feet with their uniform on
and bore at the same time the weight of so pounds,
They found. and took from the bottom of the river
gums muskets, &c. which had been lost there long
time before. Another experiment made at Pas
sau. The best swimmers separated into three par
ties, and swan for long time without touching the
earth. The first party had in their centre music
clan who played on the cIarionet. Before them OH
table was placed wine, and the swimmers drank to
| the health of the Colonel who was on the bridge.
The second party, composed Of officers, had before
them table covered with refreshments the third
also ranged themselves round the table. 1t is repre-
sented as curious spectacle to see men eating and
drinking and amusing themselves in the middle of q
stream ON tables the water bore up.
GREECE.
LONDON, Oct. 4.

full articles.headline: MAXIAIS ON EBRIETY.
full articles.article:
Drunkenness expels reason; browns the memo
ry def,ces beauty dminishes strength inilames
the blood causes internal, external and incurabe
wounds is witch to the senses a devil to the
soul thief to the purse; beggar's companion
wite's woe, and chdren's sorrow, the picture OF
a beast, and sefmurderer: who drinks TO others
good health. and robs himself of his own


Beware ofdrunkenness, lest all good men beware
Of you; when drunkenness reisns, then reasonls an
exile; virtue stranger God an enemy blasphe-
my is wit oaths are rhetoric i; and secrets are
proclamatons.


Drunkenness and eovetousness do much resemble
one another for the more man urinks, the more
he thirsteth and the more he hath, still the more
he coveteth.


In the first warm Of our liquor we begin to have
an opinion Of our wit the next degree of heat gives
mean opinion of our courage, the first errors brings
US often into quarrel: and the second makes us
come off as pitiiully


o that should put an enemy into their mouths,
To steal away their hrans.-Shakspear

full articles.headline: Cry OF Mexico, Sept. 22d. 1897.
full articles.article:
The measures pursued. and pursuing against the
Spaniards will produce, think. great changes on
the commerce Of this country, extracting large por
tons of capital and leaving the country very pour
will become more difficult TO effect sales and ex-
ceednsly dangerous to allow credits. In Jasco
the Spaniards have been expelled all soteros, and
those not married before 92l and that in the space
Of twenty days. In Acapulco, they have all been
driven to embark on board such vessels as were in
harbor to their lives many had been assassina
ted, and in Cuennayaca, abnut DAVIS travel from
this they werepursued in the streets with knives and
swords by the Peados. In Zacatecas the salne
and it is proposed in the Legislature of the State of
Mexico. that all, without exception, shall be expe-
ed the State. In fact, the movement appears to be
general, Congress will not pass a law to expel them


the country the several states it would seem are


in league to effect it individually. Many tired of
being hunted down in this manner, have resolved
themselves to leave, and suppose in twelve months
or less, there will not be an old Spanard in the Re-
public. These are the occurrences and news of the
day, from which you can draw your own differences
of the probable future condition of this country. my
own opinion is that things are going from bad to
worse,and a revolution before much time would not
surprise me, which shall end in de'potism- Chroni-
cic

full articles.headline:
From the National HfeHgencer, Nov. IA.
PUBLIC SENTIMENT IN VIRGINIA.
full articles.article:
We have received from friends in different parts
Of Virginia, as well as through the newspapers of
the state, numerous accounts of county meetings,
in addition to those heretofore noticed. The eleva
Ell character, as well as the number of the citizens
who have attended these meetings, render them
truly imposing, and justify the hope that this distn
guished Commonwealth will, at the approaching
crisis of the Institutions of the Republic, be found
on the side which compors with her ancient fame
and her undertaking support of free sovernment.-
The proceedings of several of these meetings we
have, by special resolution. been requested to pub


ish Mt large and we would cheeriuy comply, com
ing as the requests do from individuals Of SO much
respectability, many of them subscribers to pa
per, if it were not tnat compliance would exact al
most all the space of our columns. We should feel
indeed. much pleasure in publishing these proceed
ings at large. as they are in every case, accompa-
med by addresses remarkable for just views Of
publican government for their temper and ability,
and every way worthy of the citizens of free and
enlightened State. Our limits however. and the
claims of other subjects, compel us to iorego this
pleasure, and to conne notices of the Virginia


meetings to summary statements.

Last evening the storm continued with violence, and

Snow Storm The thermometer at O'Clock, was
at 81 above zero. This morning the storm has
aba'ed, but the ground is covered with and ice.


The Litchfeld Post. Conn also speaks of the
fall Of snow having been considerable in that part
f the country.


1t commenced showing at Providence on Tuesday
night and continued without ntprmssion on We'd
nesday. There was sufficient depth for sleghing.

full articles.headline:
ENGLAND.

The following appears by way of Postscriptto to the
London New Times of 4th of October
full articles.article:
AHe iolloWtnS APPEARS Ny way vi foslscrlptt0 the


London New Times of 4th of October:-


City, WeAnesday euerng


In the early part of the day the transactions in
the English Funds were of the most limited, char
acer, and the price Of Consuls nearly stationary,
alternately buyers and sellers at 81. Towards the
close Of the market, however, on the rumour
which was circulated with confidence that the Egypa
tian fleet had landed troops at Hydra, and had de-
stroyed moi only the garrison. but the chief of the
inhabitants. decline took place. and the price fell
to Sc rs 81 for Account, at which rate they ef, off
after having been 81 l-S. AT late hour in the day.
however, notice was placed on the board at lioy-
eds from the agent, under date Malta the l2th Sept.
stating that the Egyptian fleet, consisting of eighty
sail, had been fallen in with bound to the Morea, and
that Vice Admiral Sir Z. Codrington had left Smyr-
ma with twelve sail on the lst and Cd September
it also added that his Maiesty's ship Dyad and
the Hind cutter sailed from Malta to JOIN the Bri-
tish Admiral.


This threw some discredit on the original report,
but still the rumour for the moment caused very
unpleasant sensation, forit was stated that the Is
land of II, dra, which was at one time the seat Of
the Greek Government. had experienced the same
melancholy fate as those of lpsara and Reio.

full articles.headline: BuENOS AYRES.
full articles.article:
BUENOS ATRES.


Since the foregoing paragraph was written, we
have been favored BY an esteemed friend with the
following extract of letter dated


'.RIo DE JANEIRo, 22d Sept. 1927.
s'Wc have no news here things in Baenos Ayres
have run into much disorder. The provinces have
separated from that Of Buenos Ayres, but are deter
mined to agree among themselves, and to carry on
the war for the independence Of the Banda Oriental
The former confederation is dissolved, and Buenos
Ayres is now under a local government. shese peo-
Pile the Rrazllians count more upon dissentons
among their enemies, than on their own abilities to
coerce peace.'

full articles.headline: G sAsh EDsrStye,sd.
full articles.article:
THE President and Directors of the Bank Of DEL
a,care, have this day declared Dividend of Ten
Dollars per share equal to live per cent on the Cap
ital Stock for the last six months, payable to the
Stockholders, or their legal representatives on or
after the 10th inst


EDWARD WORRELL, Cash'r.
Nov 9, 1927. 60

full articles.headline: From lie NGiional Journal.
full articles.article:
From Me National Journal


We this day lay before our readers list Of
the members of the twentieth Congress, complete,
with the exception Of such have vel 10 be chosen
to fill the vacancies caused by the designations
of Mr.. Forsythe II Georgia, and Mr.. Evans, of
New York. and by the deaths of Mr.. Wilson of
Ohio, and Dr. Young Of Kentucky.


Baltimore Rail Rood.-The Managers of the
&C Baltimore and Ohio Rail Company have recev-
ed report from the Engineers, employed to survey
the several routes proposed for the Road, who re-
port that the Road is practicable, by more than one
route, though no particular one is recommended. In
cons equence of which, the Company have advertis-
ed for Timber and iron for the construction of the
Road, to be delivered in the city Of Baltimore on or
before July /, 1928.

full articles.headline: ONE DAY LATER FROM ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
The ship Hamilton, Capt. Bunker, arrived last
evening, having left Liverpool on the 3d. She brings
Liverpool papers Of the Sd, and London of the Cd
Of October, day later than those received by the
packet ship New-Tork.


Accounts from Corfu to the 29th of August have
been received in London. Achmed Pacha Of Patras,
his march to Vostizzo. had passed the monastery
of Tasiachi. where he found considerable number
of Greeks, who had taken possession of the place
without the consent of the Monks. very SAN
culinary contest took place, which terminated in the
surrender of the Greeks. The pacha afterwards
proceeded and arrived at Vostizzo with 1000 men
and 12 pieces of cannon. At Patras there was
force Of 5000 Turkish troops, who about to set
out for Modon, where Ibrahim pacha arrived on the
18th july


Spain insurrection goes on and speeds.
The rebels have appointed Regency and published
prOclanatinns in favor of .'the Absolute King =
rhe pretence is, that Ferdinand is not his own mas
ter. In the mean time the French garrisons per-
lectly quiet.


LoNDoN, Oct. 2.-Hamburgh papers of the 29th
ult reached Us last mig int. The loss sustained by
the town of Ambo by the late dreadful catastrophe
is estimated at no less than thirteen millions of rlx
dollars A terrible fire took place at Schwelin,
near Eberlield, on the 22d forty houses were
destroyed.


A manifesto of the Emperor Of Russia, dated / oh





whole Empire of two in every 500 inhabitants, not
even excepting the Jews, who have formerly been
exempt on payment Of pecuniary tax, which is to
be abolished This levy. it is supposed. will pro-
duce force of at least $50, 900 men, part of which
will have to supply the vacancies arising from death
and the discharges of those who have served their e
gal time.


MIR. Galain. the American Minister, had an in
tervew with the Earl ol Dudley, at tie Foreign of
flee.


Ledia-Late adyices from India inform us, that
severe battle has been fought in Upper India, be-
tween numerous body of the Afghan tribes, and
the troops OF ltajah Runjit Sinh. The Afghan ar
my consisted it is sad OF 90. 900 infantry Il 0,00(
horse. whilst that ef Runjit's amounted TO only be
tween 5000 and 10000 men. The armies met ~
the banks of the Indus. to the village of Seydeo
when the attack was commenced by the Afgh hans
but the greater part of their host being i'll armed ant
less organ iZed, made no impression on the Sikl1s
who put their enemies to the route In the fligh
great numbers were sabred by Runiits cavalry, and
body that bad taken shelter in the village of Sey
/ deo, was surrounded and entirely DESTROYED. The
Afgha MS lost 8 pieces of artillery. and about l0t
swvels, and their camp was punderedby the vie
/ tors


CoRFu, Sept. live have never seen such ac
tiyty in roads, and such regular communication
by post with the aeighbouring Greek Islands, al
now that the squadrons Of the Three Powers are OF
the point of joining together. Yesterday two fri
gates arrived, which are probably the rear of thu
Russian squadron, for we learn that Admiral Hey
den has been obliged by the west winds to steer II
the right Of Corfu and proceed by Strvali and Cap
Spathi to Milo, to effect his junction with the Frenc
and English squadrons. The Egyptian fleet whic
sailed from Alexandria on the 1stN of August, ha
probably received notice of the approaching junctio
Of the European squadrons, aad has endeaveured
avoid them for our last accounts from Nayarn
which come down to the 9th September, agree j
stating that not single Egyptian or Turkish YES
sci has yet been On those seas hence it is lr
Fl terred that the Egyptian fleet has either returned
; Alexandria, or that it has stecred another cours
to reach the Morca, or one of the Islands in til
: Archipelago.


: Cry OF MEXICO, Sept. e2d. 1897.
The measures pursued. and pursuing against tl
Spaniards, will produce, think. great changes o
the commerce Of this country, extracting large poi

w
rHEM. If they are to be found in his conduct in
Florida. where he placed himself, as the execu-
i've authority of the territory, above the Judiciary
and set the decisions of Judge Fromntin at detiante
making every thing to yield to his lncinations,
&C. &C. and ithey not to be found in those trans
actions, we should like 10 know 1ohen 0ere and ho7o
he acquired The character (of statesman.) In dis
cussing the qualifications OF men for office, 1hen aoe
consider them incompetent for the proper discharge
of the duties Of the stations, we wish to have nothing
~ do with gratitude and not too much with generos-
ity"


;o;ce at his prosperity but we never wish to see
linn nlaced in situation in which his extraordinary
onergu NAV turn to the disadvantage of the country.
We are willing that he should be employed against
the foes ofthe nation. but not against ourselves"


The New York papers claim decided Jackson
majority of the members of the Legislature which
have lust been elected. That the great mass of the
people Of that state do prefer Andrew Jackson to
John Quincy Adams Cor the presidency it is not
rational to believe. But that Mr.. Van Buren may
have so made his arrangements that the result OF the
election should seem to indicate such preference,
we have no doubt. Such was his especial business
and such the cherished hope of the Combination.
Martin Van Buren is one of that small number Of
men, who must bid adieu to all hope of future poll
tical advancement, unless there can be brought
about complete revouton--a total prostration of
' the Administration. Unless the men in power
can be ruined by some means, two or three would be
presidents must be forever disappointed. The prize
. is great and it must be obtained soon, or never


Martin and his Argus had denounced General
Jackson, like other men and papers of the same
character but that was not to be considered.
when it was discovered that the best chance of de-
sroyng the Administration and creating vacancy
in few years was in supporting General Jackson
I that was the only chance Of success, the hazzard
Of any revolution caused by the election of the Ge
neral was not to be regarded.


1t was seen that the General already had the sup
port of large portion of the community. from va
ous causes, not very creditable to their understand
NO and intelligence in some cases, to their pa
rotism in others. But it was too well known that
ne could not succeed as the first choice Of the Ame
rcan people and hence the absolute necessity of
employing organization prosttuted presses and po-
iticans, and using all means, fair and foul. to de-
grade the Administration, SO that majority of the





choice of eyils.H Hence we have had tale after
ale the establishment of new presses the zeal of
hose prostitutes in Virginia, Delaware. and New
York and the labors of those second rate asprants
who have slight hopes of advancement under the
present order of things.


If the Van Buren majority in the New York Le-
Eisature--caIeh sonan---chuose to take away
The power of the people to vote by districts for the
president, they may gain something for the moment;
but such course will most assuredly ruin Mr.. Van
Burcn's ulterior projects.


Besdes-supposing we allow all that the Jackso-
nians claim in Newly orl--which we very far
from doing--the signs of the times clearly indicate
that Virginia will not be counted on the side of the
&opposton. Suppose Jackson avowedly hostile to
the American system, he would be hard pushed ir
Virginia, and would probably loose all the state;
North Of the Potomac If he were as decidedly il
favor Of the American System as the present Ad
nnistraton, what has Virginia to gain by the change
N that score, and what have the people north 0
'he Potomac, seeing more fully, by and by, the rea
ohjccts Of the aspirants, to hope from a change 0
men?


Thus, therefore, when Mr.. Van Buren arrive


at Washington, in few days, he may say that h
. has done his best, according to the Combination ar
j ansements but he has much harder task t
perorm-to reconcile Virginia, Pennsylvania, an


New York to General Jackson and the policy whic


he must adopt.


Though the advocates of the Hero are SO highl


excited by the Combination operations in Newly orl
9 hey are vastly mistaken if they suppose the battle
!, won. We have yet to learn whether the people !


mat State generally, In their late vote, suppose

full articles.headline:
GREECE.

LONDON, Oct. 4.
full articles.article:
LONDON, Uct. A.
The Turks at Prevesa having heard of the decla-
ration of the allied powers, were filled with appre4
tensions, and had sent a pressing application to
Redchd Pacha for reinforcements, without which
they said that they could not prevent that fortress
from falling into the hands of the ireeks il it should
be attacked


PARIs, Sept. 80.
A report is spread. that the affairs of the Greeks
had taken more favorable turn; that Russian
Consul to the Greek Government has been appoint
ed, and that the Count Capo DIstria was going to
be officially recognised as President of Greece by
the three Allied Powers


SPAIN.


Letters from Saragossa say that conspiracy IN
favor of the rebels Of Catalonia had been discover
cd in that city, and that twenty persons Of distnc-
ton had been arrested, among whom are Mai. Gen.
Aran Frigllo, Guerilla Chief during the time OF
the constitutions Col Leon Il Brlgadier, and the
brothers Of Generals Capape and Fryre.
GyMNAsrIc. The following account of swim
ming school at Amberg. in Bavaria. we find in the
New York Statesman, taken from the papers of that
country. which give splendid accounts OF the success
of some of the scholars


The soldiers of regiment of infantry were ena-
bled to 20 down "a feet under waer and swan about
from an hour to an hour and half. They jumped
from an elevation of SO feet with their uniform on
and bore at the same time the weight of so pounds,
They found. and took from the bottom of the river
gums muskets, &c. which had been lost there long
time before. Another experiment made at Pas
sau. The best swimmers separated into three par
ties, and swan for long time without touching the
earth. The first party had in their centre music
clan who played on the cIarionet. Before them OH
table was placed wine, and the swimmers drank to
| the health of the Colonel who was on the bridge.
The second party, composed Of officers, had before
them table covered with refreshments the third
also ranged themselves round the table. 1t is repre-
sented as curious spectacle to see men eating and
drinking and amusing themselves in the middle of q
stream ON tables the water bore up.
